awd_titl_txt: Micro-Macro Scale Investigations to Study Osteocyte Mechanobiology
awd_abstract_narration:
Osteoporosis is a disease of low bone mass and increased risk of fracture. Exercise can increase bone size and help protect against fractures.  This project aims to improve understanding of how bone cells detect bone loading. The bone cell thought to be the load detector is called the "osteocyte".  Osteocytes communicate with each other and to other cells on the surface of the bone to change bone size to match the loads on the bone. The goal of the work is to determine how bone deformation and fluid flow are detected and changed into a chemical signal that the cell uses to communicate to other cells.  Mechanical loading will be related to the biological response of the cell using advanced cell biological methods. The outcomes of this research will determine the role of solid-fluid interaction mechanics in the activation of bone formation to help explain and mitigate age related bone loss. The project will offer local high school students, especially female students, one day research camps and encourage them to pursue engineering and medical education. Undergraduate students will work on various aspects of the project.

The objective is to gain a better understanding of the role of multiscale mechanics - from macro-scale bone strains to micro-scale strains (local bone matrix and lacunar strain and the corresponding fluid flow shear stress on the cell membrane) in mechanotransduction at the osteocyte cellular level. We plan to study these effects using the activation of the Wnt/beta-catenin signaling pathway in osteocytes as a readout for their response to loading. This pathway is known to be important in mediating load related bone formation. The methods include experimental studies using axial loading experiments on mouse whole forearm, novel microscale axial loading experiments on murine ulna sections using the MicroXCT-200 (Carl Zeiss/Xradia) to determine lacunar strains. Newly developed multiplexed 3D confocal microscopy techniques will be used for 3D modelling of osteocytes and their lacunar fluid space for fluid-structure interaction FE models.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Osteoporosis is a disease of low bone mass and increased risk of fracture. The osteocyte, residing inside regions of bone known as lacuna, is thought to be the mechanosensory cell in bone; however, the extent of influence and magnitude of strain and/or fluid flow at the cellular level that induces a biological response is not well understood. The objective of the NSF funded project "Micro-Macro Scale Investigations to Study Osteocyte Mechanobiology" was to use an interdisciplinary research platform to gain a better understanding of the role of mechanics, specifically the bone matrix and lacunar strain and the corresponding fluid flow shear stress on the cell membrane, in mechanotransduction at the osteocyte cellular level.

Mechanical loading is known to activate the Wnt/β-catenin pathway in osteocytes leading to the start of new bone formation. However, this activation occurs in some but not all the cells in the same region of the bone.We studied the role played by the lacuna shape, size and orientation with respect to the load using experiments and a multi-scale finite element approach. The novelty of this project was to directly correlate the pathway activation to the strain experienced by the osteocyte. This was accomplished by adapting a technique to stain for the identification of a protein product of the Wnt/β-catenin pathway, β-galactosidase using a substrate DDAOG which can be indentified in confocal imaging. This technique has not been used for bone prior to this research. This step allowed for using the confocal imaging to create numerical finite element models at the cellular level in order to determine the strains experienced by individual lacuna/osteocytes and correlate it to the activation of the pathway directly. As the measurement of mechanical strain at the lacuna in bone is impossible, we conducted experimental studies using ex vivo macro loading experiments on mouse whole forearm to measure surface strains using strain gage/digital image correlation technique and developed macro finite element (FE) models of the bone (tibia) to match the measured surface strains. We then used the strain experienced as the tibia-fibula junction from the macro FE model as input to the micro FE model which consisted of ten to fifteen osteocyte/lacunae to determine the strain in the lacuna. One Ph.D. student has worked on this aspect of the project. 

Multiscale Fluid-Structure Interaction (FSI) model and Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations were used to determine the lacunar fluid flow shear stresses (FFSS) on the membranes of the cells and dendrites at the single cell level. We developed confocal image-derived models of the osteocyte with its dendritic network and studied the magnitude and location of peak fluid shear stresses. We determined that peak pressures occurred in the dendritic process rather than on the osteocyte cell surface. Effects such as the number of dendrites, and the lacunocanalicular space size, and surface area and orientation of the cell with respect to the applied pressure were studied. It is known that the number of dendrites decreases with age. Salient findings are that shear stresses decrease with lower canalicular density and higher canalicular density results in increased total surface area, which influences the experienced shear forces on the cellular and dendritic walls. 

One of the benefits of realistic models is to consider the tortuosity of canaliculi and its influence on velocity/shear profile. Velocity does not change in straight canaliculi of the idealized models, while there is an alteration in velocity profiles of canaliculi in realistic models. Also, these variations were identified before and after branches or canalicular junctions and also in narrow channels. Narrow channels of dendrites with lower cross-section area have higher velocity and FFSS.

Broader impacts on the field and society were achieved in a variety of ways. From a technical pespective, we have developed novel experimental techniques to study the Wnt/β-catenin pathway using confocal imaging. Previous researchers have used optical imaging techniques to study the activation of this pathway. Novel multi-scale multi-modal imaging and FE techniques were developed to study the same bone at the macro and the osteocyte levels. Correlation of the pathway activation to the mechanical strain is the most novel aspect of this project. Secondly, studying the fluid flow shear stress at the cellular level was accomplished. We have involved several high school students over the years in aspects of this project by developing small projects for the students' senior year projects. We have also developed a new biomechanics based four-day high school camp which was offered for the first time at our university. Two groups of forty high school female students participated in a biomechanics/orthopedic medicine camp held as a part of this project over two years. Several undergraduate students were also involved in smaller projects related to this research and weekly meetings with graduate students helped expose them to reseach methodologies.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2021
Modified by: Ganesh Thiagarajan

Images (1 of )
  • A) 100X confocal scan with a cuboid cropped region of interest (ROI) around the lacuna, B) realistic young osteocyte model C) simulated aged osteocyte, which was generated from the same region using a thresholding process
    Mohammad Niroobakhsh
    Copyrighted
    Ganesh Thiagarajan
    Realistic single cell model for fluid flow shear stress
  • Distribution of fluid flow shear (FFSS) stress on the cell and dendrites in four idealized models. In all models, dendrites encounter higher shear stresses on the walls than the cell membrane. junction of the dendrites to the cell have also greater FFSS.
    Mohammad Niroobakhsh
    Copyrighted
    Ganesh Thiagarajan
    Fluid flow shear stress on idealized cell membrane and dendritic processes
  • Contour plots of FFSS on cell membrane and dendritic process for young and simulated aged models
    Mohammad Niroobakhsh
    Copyrighted
    Ganesh Thiagarajan
    Realistic single cell model for fluid flow shear stress
  • Confocal 40x image overlaying FITC (green), which stains the lacunocanilicular network, and DDAO (red) which indicates osteocyte activation.
    Lori Laughrey
    Copyrighted
    Ganesh Thiagarajan
    Image with multiple lacunae in a region of tibia
  • FEA colormap of a bone model made from a 40x confocal image of FITC. The model uses Tet4 elements. Colors indicate 3 Principal Lagrangian strain values. View is from a slice through the middle, in the Z-plane. Strain is amplified at the lacunar walls.
    Lori Laughrey
    Copyrighted
    Ganesh Thiagarajan
    Principal Strain in Lacunae
